awd_titl_txt: Signal Molecules in Ctenophores: Quest for the Earliest Transmitters
awd_abstract_narration:
Ctenophores, also known as comb-jellies, are marine invertebrates that show an unprecedented capacity for regenerating.  Their nervous system has two networks of interconnected cells and an elementary brain, and information travels from one nerve cell to another differently than in any other animal group. This research will reveal how comb-jellies build their nervous systems as compared to those of all other animals, and discover new molecules that control nerve cell communication in comb-jellies.  Learning about these enigmatic organisms will open new horizons in scientific knowledge about alternative ways to build nerve cells and neural circuits, and will also decipher ways to rebuild damaged nervous systems. Data from these experiments will be deposited in publically web-accessible servers for the broader scientific community. This work will also provide unique opportunities for field education and training of students and the general public by using mobile marine laboratories and digital resources that are accessible world-wide.   

Wild-captured animals from the genuses Pleurobrachia and Mnemiopsis are the major experimental models for this research. Neuron-specific, single-cell approaches will be used to study gene expression, metabolomics, proteomics, connectivity and function with the overall goal of identifying novel neurotransmitters and neural specification molecules in cell populations forming the two distinct neural nets (ectodermal vs mesoglea-derived) and aboral organ (the analog of the elementary brain) of diverse ctenophore species.  Specific outcomes will be: (1) deciphering a new chemical language in neural systems by genome-scale annotation of neurogenic and myogenic molecular pathways and transcription factors using single-cell RNA-seq and epigenome sequencing technologies; (2) tracing neuronal identities throughout development; (3) identifying and characterizing novel signal molecules or neurotransmitters using capillary electrophoresis and mass spectrometry complemented by physiological approaches; and (4) developing potential models to explain the neural origins and evolutionary diversification of synapses.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. How to make a neuron, a synapse, and a neural circuit? Is there only one 'design' for a neural architecture with a universally shared genomic blueprint across species? The brief answer is 'No'.  Here, we used animals with little-explored types of neural organizations focusing on the most enigmatic organisms: ctenophores.

            First, in a series of oceanic expeditions, we collected in nature and performed (phylo)genomic analyses of 37 ctenophore species and revealed that comb jellies are the evolutionary earliest-branching lineage, which bears neuro-muscular systems, which are most molecularly unique compared to other animals. These findings imply that nervous systems evolved more than once!  Moreover, ctenophores utilize remarkably different signaling molecules (neurotransmitters). Thus, ctenophores developed Different Chemical Alphabet and Different Chemical Language for neuronal communications or alternative neural systems. We started deciphering the cellular bases of behaviors in these 'aliens' of seas.

           Second, combining comparative single-cell sequencing, electron microscopy, and physiology, we identified four genetically distinct neuroid-type integrative systems in Ctenophores, Cnidarians, and Placozoans. We employed machine-learning algorithms to identify homologous neuronal cell types, signal molecules, and neural circuits across phyla. The resulting largest-available 'omic' dataset provides unbiased classifications of neuroid cell types with the identification of >500 novel signaling molecules. It is the foundation to establish a 'Periodic System of Neurons' with predictive power, which can be analogous to the Periodic system of chemical elements.

            Third, growing evidence supports the hypothesis of multiple origins of neurons from secretory cells in the nerveless animal ancestor. Independent events led to distinct neural nets in ctenophores controlling feeding behaviors and homeostatic functions. Surprisingly, our modeling/reconstructions suggest multiple origins of synapses in Ctenophora vs. Cnidaria vs. Bilateria. Finally, we identified non-synaptic neuroid systems in placozoans with unique manifestations of volume transmission.

            Fourth, many neuronal systems are now viewed as functional rather than genetic categories, likely composed of non-homologous cell types with different transcription factors and secretory specificity contributions. Therefore, we revise the definition of neurons as synaptically-coupled polarized and highly heterogenous secretory cells with learning capabilities at the top of behavioral hierarchies. This physiological [not phylogenetic] definition separates 'true' neurons from non-synaptically and gap junction-coupled integrative systems executing more stereotyped behaviors.  

           We started to reconstruct molecular events underlying the origins of neuronal organization in the first place. Here, injury-induced signaling associated with regenerative and morphogenic responses might be a critical factors triggering ancestral neurogenesis mechanisms. Consequently, the memory of injury could be the earliest form of memory in animal evolution. This conceptual model unites clinical pain-related and cognitive disorders' processes with fundamental genomic mechanisms underlying the parallel evolution of neural systems that eventually led to elementary cognition in different animal lineages.

            In summary, little-explored examples of convergent neuronal evolution in representatives of early branching metazoans provide conceptually novel microanatomical and physiological architectures of behavioral controls in animals with prospects of neuro-engineering and synthetic biology.

Broad Impact: This project challenges textbook viewpoints about the origin and evolution of animal complexity. We showed that there are many ways to make animals, muscles, brains, neurons, and synapses. For example, neurons and synapses might evolve >3 times, and the complex brain might be formed >20 times during evolution. A broader impact illustrates the widespread roles of convergent evolution in the development of virtually every major animal tissue. As a result,

- We outlined novel approaches and unique opportunities to take advantage of non-model organisms for deciphering the genealogy of cell types and, eventually, toward a 'Periodic System of Cell Types' with predictive power. 

- The mechanisms of convergent evolution can be widely used in the synthetic biology and regeneration medicine of the future and bioengineering. Eventually, it would contribute to designing artificial cells, neural networks, intelligence, and mind.

- In this endeavor, we developed a novel research strategy (Ship-Seq with sequencing aboard) for exploring remote ocean regions (from polar areas to the tropics), recruiting adult science citizens. This outreach program incorporated the adaptation of established marine vessel infrastructures for fundamental and applied studies as well as for training and education using resources of the world's oceans. Such approaches will eventually lead to future mobile genomic/molecular laboratories, which is critical in the face of potential pandemics and a broad spectrum of activities toward preserving global biodiversity and Planetary Health.

- We developed unique Nature-focused interdisciplinary training opportunities as a desirable educational outreach platform to disseminate scientific results and attract widespread societal attention to marine and neuroscience research. This led to a strong collaboration across the world, where we designed and maintained a program recruiting science citizens for the Ocean Genome Atlas Project, the crews of ocean-going ships, including 15,000-mile expeditions covering Hawaii, the Aleutian Islands, Alaska, the US Northwest-coast as well as retracing the famous Darwin voyage (TransAtlantic voyage) with novel genomic technologies abroad to decipher biodiversity innovations in neural and other systems.
